entry.title: diffpy.pdfgetx: Advanced Programs for Converting Powder Diffraction Data into Total Scattering Pair Distribution Functions
entry.content:
diffpy.pdfgetx3 is an advanced and powderful software for convertingPowder Diffraction data to Total Scattering atomicPair Distribution Funtions. In addtion, it can alsohelp us to extrat the PDFs from small-angle scattering(SAS).The program include three command line programs PDFgetx3, PDFgetN3 andPDFgetS3 for processing X-ray,Nertron, and Small-angle diffractiondata respectively.

Program dependencies

Authors

This code was written by members of the Billinge Group at ColumbiaUniversity and Brookhaven National Laboratory including Pavol Juh√°s,Timur Davis, Chia-Hao (Timothy) Liu, Christopher Wright, ChristopherFarrow, Connor J. Bracy, Hung Vuong, Songsheng Tao, SimonBillinge.
Prof. Simon Billinge (E-mail: sb2896@columbia.edu)
The Billinge Group
The BILLINGE GROUP: COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY
Department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics
The Billinge Group

Installation

Obtain the Software

The PDFgetX3, PDFgetN3 and PDFgetS3 software can be obtained for freefrom Columbia Technology Ventures, provided it will beused for open academic research (Recommendation: Cite therelevant paper.).

The Complicated process

Visit the official software website and follow the proceduresat:

Install the Software

Download the appropriate version of Python for youroperating system.
Download Python
In China, to speed up the downloading of packages via pip, it isrecommended to use a domestic mirror site. Now, open the terminal andrun the following command.

Other mirror,
Open Source Mirrors

Windows (not Recommended)

Open the terminal, CMD or Powershell and run,

Linux (Recommended)

Open the terminal and run,

Check Installation

pdfgerx3

Overview

PDF data analysis typically consists of threeparts:

  • Obtaining one-dimensional diffraction data (e.g., usingFit2D, Dioptas)
  • Extracting the total scattering pair distribution function (PDF)from the diffraction data (e.g., using diffpy.pdfgetx)
  • Modeling analysis of the PDFs (e.g., using RMCProfile,DISCUS).

diffpy.pdfgetx can readily process hundreds of powder diffractionpatterns within a few seconds. With an ad hoc data reductionand correction algorithm, pdfgetxns3 requires little user input,generates PDFs in a fraction of a second, and can be straightforwardlyautomated to batch process thousands of PDFs.

Workflow

Ensure that the two-dimensional data have beencorrectly azimuthally integrated and that multiple frames havebeen summed or averaged to obtain a one-dimensional profile of intensityversus Q or intensity versus .

flowchart LR    A(Load .chi Data) -->B(Configuration)    B --> C(Command)    C --> D(Export Data)    C --Refine parameter--> B

Get Started

Preparation

.chi file

The TwoTheta data or QA or Qnm data.
Such as,

Help

Open the Terminal and type the following command to access the helpmenu.

Then, switch to the filepath where we saved the datafile.

Generate the Configuration

We should create the configuration file for the programs.
The default name for config files,

pdfgetx3pdfgetn3pdfgers3
pdfgerx3.cfgpdfgetn3.cfgpdfgets3.cfg
.pdfgetx3.cfg.pdfgetn3.cfg.pdfgets3.cfg

If a configuration file is not specified with the command, theprogram will search for pdfgetx3.cfg or.pdfgetx3.cfg to load.

Open the config file with a text editor. The lines that start with ahash mark # are comments and are exclueded. TheCritial Options for PDFs calculation:

OptionsDescription
dataformattwotheta or QA or Qnm
wavelengthRequired for TwoTheta Data. Radiationwavelength
compositionChemical composition of thespecimen
qmaxinstQ boundary of the instrument
qmaxQ cutoff range for Fourier Tansform

Run

The structure of command of pdfgerxns3 is

Options control the program, and 'inputN' specifies thetotal scattering data in a .chi file.

#for pdfgerx3pdfgetx3 --verbode=info -t gr FileName.chi --plot=fq,gr#for pdfgern3pdfgetn3 --verbode=info -t gr FileName.chi --plot=fq,gr#for pdfgets3pdfgets3 --verbode=info -t gr FileName.chi --plot=fq,gr#--verbose=info    -print the information#-t gr   save the gr data (PDFs data)#--plot=fq,gr    plot f(q) and g(r) also can plot i(q) and s(q)

Have a try.

Now, the program has finished, and we have obtained the PDFs with thefile name extersion .gr. pdfgetxns3 enters an IPython sessionin interactive mode. For more about interactive mode, refer to SectionInteractive Mode.

Input

Command

Output

Batch Processing

Interactive Mode

Physical Theory of PDFs

The PDF is a probability distribution function inreal-space.

How to Obtain PDFsfrom Total Scattering

Coherent Scattering

The internsity measured in a total scattering experimentIm(Q)

  • Ic(Q) is the intensity of coherent scattering whichcontains all of the structural information about thesample Signal
  • a(Q) and b(Q) are additive and multipicativecorrections to Im(Q) which do not containstructural information. (Such as Compton Scattering, Scatteringfrom the sample container) Noise

Structure Function

To obtain the coherent scattering Ic(Q) we divideIm(Q) by the number of scatterers, N, and theaverage scattering powder per atom. So, we have accquired the structurefunction, S(Q).
For the X-ray Powder Diffraction or Small-angleScattering,
Here, f(Q) is the atomic scattering factor and theangle brackets indicate an average over all the atom types in thesample.
For the Neutron Powder Diffraction or Small-angleScattering,
where bi is the coherent neutronscattering length of atom i, and the angle brackets indicate anaverage over all atoms in the sample.

Tips:
Despite the tricky definition, it is worth remembering thatS(Q) is nothing other than the powderdiffraction pattern that has been corrected for experimentalartifacts and suitably normalized.
Corrections include, but are not limited to, background subtraction,polarization, self-absorption, multiple scattering, and Comptonscattering.

FT(Reduced StructureFunction)

Total scattering data can be analyzed by fitting models directly inreciprocalspace (i.e., the S(Q) function is fit).However, an alternative and intuitive approach is to Fouriertransform the data to real-space to obtain theatomic pair distribution functions (PDF), which isthen fit in real-space. The reduced pair distribution function,, is related toS(Q) through a sine Fourier transform according to:

where the quantify F(Q) is the reduced structurefunction.

PDFs is the Fourier transformresult of the reduced structure functionF(Q).

Coherent scattering (also known asRayleigh, unmodified,classical or elastic scattering) is one of three formsof photon interaction which occurs when the energy of the x-ray or gammaphoton is small in relation to the ionization energy of the atom (forinstance, during mammography). Such low-energy radiation triggers allthe electrons in an atom to vibrate at a similar frequency to theincident photon. Upon interacting with the attenuating medium, thephoton does not have enough energy to liberate the electron from itsbound state (i.e. the photon energy is well below the binding energy ofthe electron) so no energy transfer occurs. There is no energydeposition and thus no dose resulting from coherent scattering. The onlychange is a change of direction (scatter) of the photon, hence'unmodified' scatter. Coherent scattering is not a major interactionprocess encountered in radiography at the energies normally used.

Algorithm of pdfgetxns3

Data preprocessing

For data, itwill be converted to the scattering vector magnitude Q and re-sampledonto an equidistant Q grid.

Note that resampling introduces error correlations between points,which can be minimized if the data are azimuthally integrated from twodimensions directly onto a constant-Q grid.

Q is the magnitude of the scattering vector, where: The vector is the physicist's equivalent of the crystallographer's . The physical meaning of is the momentumtransfer on scattering and differs from the scattering vector by a factor of

Background Subtraction

The scattering data from an empty sample container will besubtracted.
This yeilds raw scattering intensities from the specimenonly.

Normalization

Acquir the F(Q)
The S(Q) should oscillate around and the approach unity as Qincreasing to infinity.

The coherent intensity (the features) in S(Q) dies out withincreasing Q due to the Debye‚ÄìWaller factor, which comes fromthermal and quantum zero-point motion of the atoms as well as any staticdisplacive disorder in the material. By a Q-value of 30‚Äì50 (depending on temperatureand stiffness of the bonding) there are no more features inS(Q) and there is no need to measure tohigher-Q.

This told us that the normalized intensity must be close to the normal scattering factor . pdfgetxns3 will use aleast-squares to approach the normal scattering factor.Assumption of pdfgetxns3 algorithm:

  • the difference between Experimental Sm(Q) with the realS(Q) is
  • can be modeling byan n-th-degree polynomial

Allown for the following derivation:

Error

Finally, this leads an error signal , extending up to,

This means that the error signal arising from the ploynomial datacorrection is only present for lengths smaller than rploy(Smaller than the physically and chemically meaningfuldistance). For example, if rploy=0.8 Angstrom,the exist atlengths smaller than 0.8 Angstrom.

rpoly is chosen to be below thenearest neighbor bond distance in the material

Reference

[1] Juh√°s, P., Davis, T., Farrow, C. . and Billinge, S. . . (2013),PDFgetX3: a rapid and highly automatable program for processing powderdiffraction data into total scattering pair distribution functions. J.Appl. Cryst., 46: 560-566.https://doi.org/10.1107/S0021889813005190
[2] Juh√°s, P., Louwen, J.N., van Eijck, L., Vogt, E. . and Billinge, S.. (2018), PDFgetN3: atomic pair distribution functions from neutronpowder diffraction data using ad hoc corrections. J. Appl. Cryst., 51:1492-1497. https://doi.org/10.1107/S1600576718010002
[3] Liu, C. H., Janke, E. M., Li, R., Juh√°s, P., Gang, O., Talapin, D.V., & Billinge, S. J. (2020). sasPDF: pair distribution functionanalysis of nanoparticle assemblies from small-angle scattering data.Journal of Applied Crystallography, 53(3), 699-709.
[4] https://www.diffpy.org/doc/pdfgetx/2.2.1/intro.html

Resources

PDFs: past and present

Zeitschrift f√ºr Kristallographie - Crystalline Materials

RA-PDF analysis

Journal of Applied Crystallography

Nanostructure

Nature

A guide to PDFs

Zeitschrift f√ºr Kristallographie - Crystalline Materials

Manualfa-solid fa-arrow-up-right-from-square

entry.title: Use Dioptas for Efficient 2D Powder Diffraction Data Reduction
entry.content:
Dioptas is an awesome GUI program based on Python, designedfor the fast data reduction of Powder X-ray Diffractionimages. It provides the capability ofcalibrating, integrating,creating masks, showing multiple pattern overlays anddisplay phases line positions.

Program dependencies

Authors

Maintainer

Clemens Prescher (clemens.prescher@gmail.com)

Installation

Executables

Binary programs for Windows, macOS, and Linux can be downloaded fromthe following link:

pip

Install the all the dependencies for Dioptas by pip packagemanager:

poetry
Use the poetry package manager to create a working environment bytyping:

Procedure

Overview

Dioptas has three different modules which can all be accessed by thelab indicators on the left side of the userinterface: Calibration, Mask,Integration.

  • Calibration Module This module is used to calibratethe detector geometry.
  • Mask Module This module allows users to selectregions that need to be excluded from the image integration.
  • Integration Module This module displays the imageand integrated pattern. It can overlay different patterns and show theline positions of phases.

Getting Started

Basic Mouse Operations

  • Left Drag
  • Right Drag
  • Right Click
  • Right Double Click
  • Mouse Wheel
  • Left Drag Zooms into the selected area.
  • Right Drag Move the image.
  • Right Click Zoom out.
  • Right Double Click Completely Zoom out.
  • Mouse Wheel Zoom in and zoom out based on thecurrent cursor position.

Image Color Scale andContrast

The image color scale and contrast can be adjusted by slidingthe color bar and right-clicking to change the color group.

Workflow

Step 1 Calibrate

Load the image data of the calibrant to perform thecalibration and refinement procedures. Usually, the calibrant is acompound with a known and stable crystal structure, such asLaB6, CeO2, Cr2O3, etc.

flowchart LR    A(Load Image Data) -->B(Calibration)    B --> C(Mask)    C --> D(Integration)    D --> E(Save Calibration or Export Data)

Step 2 Load 2D Image andCovert to 1D

Load the image data of samples to extract structuralinformation. 

flowchart LR    A(Load Image Data) -->B(Mask)    B --> C(Integration)    C --> D(Export Data)    C --> A

Batch Mode Multiple dataprocessing is discussed in Section 4.6 Integration Procedure.

Let's start by loading theimage data.
Click the button the on the upper right side of the interface to begin theprocess.
  • Calibration
  • Mask
  • Integration

Calibration Procedure

The calibration procedure aims to correct the detector geometry andfind the beam center.

Preparation

First, click the buttonlocated on the left side of thewindow to enter calibration mode. The wavelength and pixelwidth/height have to be defined based on theexperimental setup and detector used.

Start values
Required Parameter Setting:

  • Calibrant (standardcomplex)
  • wavelength
  • pixel size (width, height)
  • Approximate Distance (the programwill automatically refine the value)

Peak Picking

Peak Selection
After selecting the 'Calibration Parameter', Dioptas requires an initialguess for the ring positions to determine the correct geometry. Selectseveral points on each diffraction ring to proceed. OK, now,left-click at the location where webelieve the first diffraction ring appears. Calibrationdose not need to start from the first diffraction ring.

Calibration does not need to start from the first diffraction ring,which enables calibration of detector geometries with the beam centerbeing far outside of the area of the detector. But we ought to make surethat current peak number belongs to the corresponding clicked ring.

If the default automatic peak search is enabled,simply left-click the first diffraction ring as shown in this figure.Zooming in on the image will help accurately target the firstring.
If the automatic peak searching fails, we can try the followingalternatives:

  • Perform the automatic search on the second, third, or subsequentrings.
  • Choose the single peak search option.
  • automatic peak search
  • single peak search

Left click the localtion of the fistdiffraction rings. The peak search routine will automatically detect theremaining diffraction rings when we click the button,located at the bottom left.

Left-click on the location of a diffraction ring; the program will markthe maximum peak around the clicked area. TheSearch size determines the searcharea. We should select as many diffraction rings as possible. - one peakfor one diffraction ring (select theautomatic increase)

Calibrate and Refine

Calibrate

Calibrate
After the ring have been selected we can start the calibrationprocedure. button, located at the bottom left. When the procedure is finished,Dioptas will switch to the Cake Tab.We can click on the pattern table to check if all peaks in the patterncoincide with the phase line positions. Check whether the calibration issuccessful. - the cake lines are straight - all peak in the pattern arecoincided with phase line position

Refinement Options

After calibration and refinement, Dioptas will automatically create a360 degree cake image and anintegrated pattern. Some options can be defined. For high-qualitydiffraction data, it is recommended to set the intensity minimumfactor to about 1-1.5.
For other parameters, refer to the manual.

File Handing

Save Calibration
Save the calibration parameter as a .poni file for futureuse.
Load Calibration
Load a previously saved clibration.

Mask Creation

Create a mask to define areas that should be excluded from integrationor calibration.

A mask excludes specific areas from the integration process, whichenables the removal of unwanted features such as, for example, diamondreflections in diamond anvil cell experiments, saturated peaks ordetector blemishes. Available geometries for creating masks are circles,rectangles and polygons.

  • mask
  • unmask

Mask

Choose a shape and left-click to set a start point, then drag the mouseto adjust the size of the shape, and finally left-click again to set theendpoint.

Unmask

Choose a shape and left-click to set a start point, then drag the mouseto adjust the size of the shape, and finally left-click again to set theendpoint.

File Handing

Save Mask
Save the mask as a .mask file for future use.
Load Mask
Load a previously saved mask and clear the current maskbefore
Add Mask
add Load a previously saved mask and add it into currentmask.

Integration Procedure

The core component of Dioptas where we can automatically integratemultiple images to pattern, browse between images and integratedpattern, compare multiple pattern to each other, perform backgroundsubtraction and compare pattern peak positions and intensities to theones of known phases.

Bathch Processing

Image

  • Check the autoprocess
  • Click the to setan input folder

Pattern

  • Check the autocreate
  • Click the to setan output folder

There are two mode for browing,

  • By Name test_001.tif test.002.tif ... |test_001.chi test_002.chi ...
  • By Time files will be searched based on creationtime.

The output file type can be changed by checking the box in the lowerright of the Pattern Tab.

Exporting Data

Click Save to save the pattern as the desired file type.If we click the 'Save' button on the left, we will save the Dioptasproject.

To be continued ...

References

[1] Prescher,Clemens, and Vitali B. Prakapenka. ‚ÄúDIOPTAS: A Program for Reduction ofTwo-Dimensional X-Ray Diffraction Data and Data Exploration.‚Äù HighPressure Research 35, no. 3 (2015): 223‚Äì30.doi:10.1080/08957959.2015.1059835.
[2] Dioptas 0.4.0documentation
[3] github.com/Dioptas/Dioptas.git

ManualGithub

entry.title: XAFS Theory
entry.content:
XAFS is an element-specific spectroscopy in which measurements aremade by tuning the X-ray energy at and above a selected core-levelbinding energy of a specified element. Although XAFS is awell-established technique providing reliable and useful informationabout the chemical and physical environment of the probe atom, itsrequirement of an energytunable X-ray source means it is primarily donewith synchrotron radiation sources and so is somewhat less common thanother spectroscopic analytical methods. XAFS spectra are especiallysensitive to the oxidation state and coordination chemistry of theselected element.

Theory
